channel.title: BBC News - World
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pfizer becomes first Covid vaccine to gain full FDA approval
item.description: It is the first Covid jab to receive federal approval, and opens the door to new vaccine mandates.

item.title: Poland to build Belarus border fence after migrant influx
item.description: Poland and its EU allies have accused Belarus of weaponising migrants in response to sanctions.

item.title: Tennessee flash floods kill 22 with dozens missing
item.description: The death toll is expected to rise after record-breaking rainfall triggered widespread flooding.

item.title: Storm Henri: Lightning strikes One World Trade Center
item.description: The strike was captured as Storm Henri approached the north-east of the US, bringing heavy rain.

item.title: Mozambique 'tuna bond' scandal: Ex-President Guebuza's son on trial
item.description: Mozambique's biggest corruption scandal led donors to cut funding and an economic crisis.

item.title: Joséphine Baker to be first black woman to enter France's Panthéon
item.description: Performer and World War Two resistance fighter Joséphine Baker will be honoured at the mausoleum.

item.title: Israeli strikes on Gaza high-rises may be war crimes - Human Rights Watch
item.description: Four tower blocks were destroyed by Israeli forces during May's conflict with Palestinian militants.

item.title: Hurricane Grace: Mexican man buries wife and five children killed in mudslide
item.description: A man and his son were the only members of a family of eight to survive a mudslide in Mexico.

item.title: Covid: Taiwan rolls out homegrown vaccine amid criticism
item.description: Taiwan's president was vaccinated with the country's first domestically developed jab named Medigen.

item.title: Chip giant's IPO hit by Beijing crackdown on business
item.description: The share listing of BYD Semiconductor has been suspended due to a regulatory investigation.

item.title: French match abandoned after player hit by bottle
item.description: Nice versus Marseille is abandoned after Dimitri Payet throws a bottle back into the crowd and fans storm the pitch.

item.title: Afghanistan: People at Kabul airport flee Taliban with just a suitcase
item.description: Afghans waiting at Kabul airport tell the BBC of their pain at fleeing the country they love.

item.title: Wuhan lab leak theory: How Fort Detrick became a centre for Chinese conspiracies
item.description: Apparent Chinese propaganda efforts are spreading ahead of a US report on Covid-19 origins.

item.title: Kamala Harris joins diplomatic charm offensive in South East Asia
item.description: The US vice-president's trip to the region falls in the shadow of a chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan.

item.title: Barakat: First South African film in Cape Town's Afrikaans dialect
item.description: Barakat, or blessing, is the first film in Afrikaaps - a dialect of Afrikaans spoken in Cape Town.

item.title: C-17: The US military plane carrying Afghans to safety
item.description: A Boeing C-17 safely carried 823 Afghans from Kabul last week, a record number for that plane.

item.title: Nigeria's royal wedding: Private jets, glitz and glamour
item.description: President Buhari's son marries the daughter of a religious leader in one of Nigeria's events of the year.

item.title: Dorothy Butler Gilliam: 'I am not a maid, I am a reporter'
item.description: The first black female reporter on the Washington Post says some colleagues would pretend not to know her.

item.title: Afghanistan: The BBC's Lyse Doucet reports from Kabul airport
item.description: The BBC's Lyse Doucet witnesses Afghan men, women and children fleeing the Taliban regime.

item.title: Afghan activist: Either we let them kill us or keep working
item.description: A leading campaigner for women's rights in Afghanistan was evacuated from Kabul last week, after going into hiding.

item.title: Tennessee: Drone video shows damage from flash floods
item.description: Heavy rainfall in the US state causes deadly flash floods, destroying homes and sweeping away cars.

item.title: Kenya holds biggest ever animal census
item.description: All wildlife on land and sea is being counted to help Kenya's conservation plans and tourism.

item.title: How Afghanistan's media is changing under Taliban rule
item.description: The Taliban are currently on a media offensive but does their rhetoric match what’s happening on the ground?

item.title: Afghanistan: Foreign troops extension 'a clear violation' - Taliban
item.description: A Taliban spokesman says Afghans with passports can leave on commercial flights "at any time".

item.title: Afghanistan: Where will refugees go after Taliban takeover?
item.description: Thousands of people are scrambling to flee Afghanistan after the Taliban took control of the country.

item.title: Hours without food or water in Kabul airport 'hell'
item.description: An Afghan man who worked for the British army tells the BBC he and his family cannot get through the crowds.

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: 'Hey world, do you care what happens here?'
item.description: A young woman shares her fears a week after the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghan baby girl born on US evacuation flight
item.description: The woman went into labour en route to Ramstein Air Base in Germany and gave birth on the plane.

item.title: Afghanistan: The desperate scramble to escape
item.description: The BBC witnesses scenes of chaos and panic as thousands still crowd Kabul's airport.
